user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimedWrite:
```c
int32 OS_TimedWrite(osal_id_t filedes, const void *buffer, size_t nbytes, int32 timeout)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(nbytes);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_GenericWrite_Impl(&token, buffer, nbytes, timeout);
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the call passes the address of a local OS_object_token_t to a release function which is expected to modify the token (e.g. clear it or update refcount). Rule 8.13 only requires pointers to point to const-qualified types when the pointed-to object is not modified. If OS_ObjectIdRelease actually does not modify the token, then the violation would be in the function prototype/implementation (its parameter should be declared as pointing to a const-qualified type). Also token cannot be declared const here because it is written by OS_ObjectIdGetById, so this call does not violate Rule 8.13.
